Posts.Title: Ritalin again raro K-Lo

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2012 09:56AM Irishbrat wrote: I just started this 2 weeks ago after reading the first "Ritalin" thread.... I can't believe how much better I feel - even my teenage kids noticied a difference.  So glad that you ladies pointed me in that direction - not sure why more Onc's don't prescribe it..... I say give it a try - just make sure that you get your throid tested - it must be normal.  ~Shannon
Posts.Title: Ritalin again raro K-Lo

Posts.Content: Irishbrat wrote: So as I am sitting here at work - thinking about my test results from today.  Not as good as I wanted - but not the worst by far...... I am NED except one pesky met in my hip...so just a change up in meds.... Anyway - I received the best text message from my 15 year old daughter..... "I was just thinking that 2 years ago on this day you told me you had cancer  but now you are all better!  And I wanted to tell you I love youuuu" These are the moments in life - that so make everything worth it!  I wish everyone the best - please remember to cherish every moment!!! Hugs  (((Shannon))) Life is Short - Cry Less, Love More, Laugh til it Hurts and Cherish Every Moment Dx 4/16/2009, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 2, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 4/16/2009 Chemotherapy 1/1/2010 Taxol (paclitaxel) Hormonal Therapy 4/1/2011 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Radiation Therapy 7/7/2011 Bone Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: OT good news Padiddle DianeKS

Posts.Content: Irishbrat wrote: Hi Everyone, Sorry I have not posted lately - and I missed the Michigan get together in August .... But I needed to take a break from everything.... But the good news is that I did receive my accelerated life insurance benefit.  It took me a long time to build up the courage to ask my Onco to sign the paperwork - but she did - like no big deal ..... and in 7 days I had my check!  It has been the best decision that I have made.... So those of you worrying about what others might think - I say go for it if you can!!  Having extra money in the bank has helped relieve so much stress for me... I can now enjoy a few extra special vacations with my kids - I can also put the money away for them, as I choose - they are old enough now (14 and 15), that I am starting to share/discuss with them, the way that I think they should use the money for their futures.  ( I am a single mom) I really hope that everyone that can - really takes advantage of this ..... we deserve some kind of perk with everything else that we are going through!!! I hope that you are all doing well ..... Take Care! ~Shannon Life is Short - Cry Less, Love More, Laugh til it Hurts and Cherish Every Moment Dx 4/16/2009, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 2, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 4/16/2009 Chemotherapy 1/1/2010 Taxol (paclitaxel) Hormonal Therapy 4/1/2011 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Radiation Therapy 7/7/2011 Bone Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: stage 4-5-what the hell? sharalou 3rings

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2012 10:24AM Irishbrat wrote: Nancy, take pride in what you have accomplished!  I too had to cut back my hours - and after I got over my own personal disappointment in myself - I realized that it was the best thing for me and my family.  In the long (and short) run - it was also the best thing for my employer.  I am much more focused at work - and then able to be there for my kids..... no more quilt!!   Happily - I have reached a place that I might be able to increase my work hours - but it will be on my terms.... Maintaining a healthy balance is very important - so make sure you are doing what you need to do for yourself. Also - becareful how you reduce your hours - you may qualify for disability while still working - I do!!  So having that income offset the reduced hours is a huge help! Take Care, Shannon

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2010 01:47PM Irishbrat wrote: ..... I actually just joined this group to answer this question.  I have/had mets to my sternum, spine and sacrum.  When I started chemo the pain in these areas increased.  According to my onc. bone mets healing is like a fracture or broke bone healing - so there is pain.  Over time the pain decreased and YAY my last PET scan showed clear.  Your PET/CT scan will show the difference - so hang in there.  I have learned that not all pain is bad! Good Luck!  Shannon

Posts.Title: Well, now, that was awkward!! Mzmerz justjudie

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2013 12:22PM Irishbrat wrote: Hi Jennifer... thank you for the much needed laugh today.... I will forever think of radiation in a different way :)  I was able to get an extra year out of Faslodex by radiating - strangely my hip area!  I did 10 treatments of the area - and after about the 5th one - I could already tell the difference in the pain level.  Once thing to watch, esp. with the hip area - is your white blood count.  Your hip area has a lot of your body's bone marrow - so I would just say to be careful of that! If you are being scanned (watched) closely by your Onco - and you have a comfort/trust level with them - I would say "milk it" the Faslodex that is - for all its worth!!!  Good Luck! ((Hugs)) ~Shannon
